To say that someone or something expands with the universe is a meaningless tautology. The universe is our ultimate frame of reference, there is nothing beyond the fabric of space and time that we can use as a frame of reference. Therefore if something expands with the universe, It doesnt make a difference to say that it does not expand at all. This is because our frame of reference would be expanding with it.

Another important point to make is that the Universe can be defined as the set of all things that exist. It is impossible for something to exist outside the universe and expanding with the universe.

So the correct title should be, "Is the Universe expanding?" Or "Are we expanding like the rest of the Universe is?" Notice that the second option uses "the rest" to avoid including "us" two times because if we are already part of the universe, it doesnt make sense to say that we are expanding with it.

Proof by contradiction:

If the universe was expanding and we were not. Then we would not be part of the universe. By definition, everything that exists is part of the universe so we have reached the contradiction.

We can conclude not only that we are indeed expanding with the universe but also that the title of the video does no make sense from a logical standpoint.

In other words: assuming that distant light sources consist of the same types of matter we know on earth, certain prominent patterns in their spectra are most easily explained by interpreting them as somewhat redshifted.

You can tell from the spectrum (graph of emitted light intensity over the light wavelength) of a distant light source (e.g. a star). Each chemical element or molecule in the star absorbs and emits some very specific wavelengths (absorption/emission lines) when it is sufficiently energized and leaves that pattern of peaks and dips in the spectrum. If you recognize the pattern of some substance you'll get the redshift by measuring by how much the pattern was shifted along the x-axis (wavelength).

Watch the video again.  Objects don't expand.  As I mention in another post the expanding rubber analogy is what is causing your confusion, as something drawn becomes larger as the rubber stretches, but that is not what really happens.  Your metal bar will stay the same size, it is just that there will be more "empty" space between it and metal bars in distant galaxies in the future.  Nothing is "pushing" the bars apart.  Each still sits in its original place.

The Great Attractor is about 250 million light years) in the direction of the constellations Hydra and Centaurus  This is close to the plane of our galaxy which makes it very difficult to study in visual light because of all of the dust and stars block visual light, but we have some data about it in X-ray.  You can do some research, but I think the latest is that although there is a heck of a big clump of large older galaxies there, it might be predominately a giant gathering of dark matter.

This is where the expanding rubber sheer or ballon analogy totally falls apart.  If you draw on the rubber and then stretch the rubber, your drawing would get bigger too, which is incorrect.  Think of matter more like little pieces of felt scattered around.  The pieces stay the same size and in the same spot on the rubber, it is just that more rubber keeps appearing between the pieces.  Only on scales larger than galactic clusters does expansion become noticeable over gravitational effects.

'Expand' isn't really an accurate term for this. I don't think there is a word that can sum up what's happening. What's happening is that distances are doubling over time.

Place a finger on another point of the balloon and blow air into it. When you look at the dot, your finger is moving away from it and vice versa.

For many years I believed that the red shift was a consequence of the expansion of the universe, then I found out that this notion was incorrect. The overall rate of space-time expansion in the universe is far too slow to account for the observed red shift. The shift in wavelength is attributed to space-time dilation or contraction from speed  - time is ticking at different rates in different galaxies as they move away or towards us - a Doppler shift. Alas, red shifts are not seen in all quasars

The first object only moved 2m, but that second object moved 200m in the same amount of time, making it 'faster'.

The redshifted light he mentioned in the video is the Doppler effect. It is used to determine whether a distant celestial object is moving towards or away from us. Through observation, it appeared that most objects were generally moving away from US. They later figured it must be the expansion of space, and depending on where it's observed from, that point would be the apparent "centre"; as in our case the Earth. Everything was moving away from us, yet at the same time also from everything else.

Here's an interesting fact regarding time dilation.  If we could get a spaceship to move at speeds near the speed of light, then we would be able to actually time travel to the future (but not back)!  This is because of time dilation.  When traveling near the speed of light, people at slower speeds perceive it as taking years for you to return.  But to you it could just be a quick round trip.  Time travel forward is an actual thing, but we lack the means to do it.

Calling something an assumption is in itself trivial. The existence of the universe is an assumption, too. The important question is not wether something is an assumption, but rather how reasonable this assumption is. And the redshift being caused by the cosmic expansion is very reasonable, because 1) it is consistent with the known behavoir of light and 2) it lead to statements that have been confirmed by observations, e.g. microwave background a.o.

As with most things, it's about predictions. The expansion of the Universe is only taken as a matter of course because it's the only thing that both explains the events we see AND that makes accurate predictions about the shape of the Universe. If it weren't expanding, then we would expect to see some radically different shapes to the clumps of stars in the sky. It's both of these things, taken together, that leads us to believe that the Universe is expanding, not just doppler shift.
